factoid: Prince Andrew ordered his horse to be saddled.
Prince Andrew left his regiment on the march.
Prince Andrew rode to his father's estate.
Prince Andrew had been born at his father's estate.
Prince Andrew spent his childhood at his father's estate.
Prince Andrew rode past the pond.
The pond used to have dozens of women chattering as they rinsed linen or beat it with wooden beetles.
Prince Andrew noticed that there was not a soul about.
Prince Andrew noticed that the little washing wharf was floating on its side in the middle of the pond.
The little washing wharf was torn from its place and half submerged.
Prince Andrew rode to the keeper's lodge.
No one was at the stone entrance gates of the drive.
The door of the keeper's lodge stood open.
Grass had begun to grow on the garden paths.
Horses and calves were straying in the English park.
Prince Andrew rode up to the hothouse.
Some of the glass panes of the hothouse were broken.
Some of the trees in tubs were overturned.
Some of the trees in tubs were dried up.
Prince Andrew called for Tarás the gardener.
No one replied to Prince Andrew's call.
Prince Andrew went round the corner of the hothouse to the ornamental garden.
Prince Andrew saw that the carved garden fence was broken.
Branches of the plum trees had been torn off with the fruit.
An old peasant whom Prince Andrew had often seen at the gate in his childhood was sitting on a green garden seat.
The old peasant was plaiting a bast shoe.
The old peasant was deaf.
The old peasant did not hear Prince Andrew ride up.
The old peasant was sitting on the seat the old prince used to like to sit on.
Strips of bast were hanging on the broken and withered branch of a magnolia beside the old peasant.
Prince Andrew rode up to the house.
Several limes in the old garden had been cut down.
A piebald mare and her foal were wandering in front of the house among the rosebushes.
The shutters of the house were all closed.
One window of the house was open.
A little serf boy saw Prince Andrew and ran into the house.
Alpátych had sent his family away.
Alpátych was alone at Bald Hills.
Alpátych was sitting indoors reading the Lives of the Saints.
Alpátych heard that Prince Andrew had come.
Alpátych went out with his spectacles on his nose.
Alpátych was buttoning his coat.
Alpátych began weeping and kissing Prince Andrew’s knee without a word.
Alpátych turned away and began to report on the position of affairs.
Everything precious and valuable had been removed to Boguchárovo.
Seventy quarters of grain had been carted away.
The hay and the spring corn had been commandeered by the troops.
The hay and the spring corn had been mown down while still green.
The peasants were ruined.
Some peasants had gone to Boguchárovo.
Only a few peasants remained.
Prince Andrew asked when his father and sister left.
Prince Andrew meant when his father and sister left for Moscow.
Alpátych understood the question to refer to their departure for Boguchárovo.
Alpátych replied that they had left on the seventh.
Alpátych went into details concerning the estate management.
Alpátych asked for instructions.
Prince Andrew inquired whether to let the troops have the oats.
Prince Andrew inquired whether to take a receipt for the oats.
Prince Andrew said that they still had six hundred quarters left.
Prince Andrew thought what to say to the old man.
Prince Andrew looked down on the old man's bald head shining in the sun.
Prince Andrew saw by the expression on the old man's face that the old man understood how untimely such questions were.
Prince Andrew saw that the old man only asked them to allay his grief.
Prince Andrew replied that the troops should have the oats.
Alpátych said that if he noticed some disorder in the garden it was impossible to prevent it.
Alpátych said that three regiments had been here and spent the night.
Alpátych said that the regiments were mostly dragoons.
Alpátych said that he took down the name and rank of their commanding officer.
Alpátych said that he would hand in a complaint about it.
Prince Andrew asked whether Alpátych would stay if the enemy occupied the place.
Alpátych turned his face to Prince Andrew.
Alpátych looked at Prince Andrew.
Alpátych raised his arm with a solemn gesture.
Alpátych exclaimed that he is my refuge.
Alpátych exclaimed that his will be done.
A group of bareheaded peasants was approaching across the meadow toward Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew said "Good‑by!"
Prince Andrew bent over to Alpátych.
Prince Andrew told the old man to go away too.
Prince Andrew told the old man to take away what he could and to tell the serfs to go to the Ryazán estate or to the one near Moscow.
Alpátych clung to Prince Andrew’s leg.
Alpátych burst into sobs.
The prince gently disengaged himself.
Prince Andrew spurred his horse.
Prince Andrew rode down the avenue at a gallop.
